story.storykicker: She used to study under a kerosene lamp till class 5, as there was no electricity in her village
story.storybody:
Despite belonging to a poor family and living in dearth of basic needs, this Odisha girl made it to the top few in the Odisha Joint Entrance Exam. Haripriya Nayak topped the exam for the Bachelors of Ayurveda, Medicine and Surgery, Bachelors of Homeopathic Medicine and surgery and pharmacy.

(Read: Assam Class 10 board results 2016 declared at www.resultsassam.nic.in )

Haripriya's fight against all the odds:

  • "I have achieved this due to the blessings of my parents, inspiration of my teachers and my hard work," told Haripriya to HT
  • Nayak's father is a marginal farmer was a dropped out of school before class 10, and her mother studied only upto class 6
  • She used to study under a kerosene lamp till class 5, as there was no electricity in her village
  • Despite meagre monetary conditions, Nayak appeared for the entrance exam because of her teachers who insisted her to take an exam for Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya (JNV)
  • Funded by the central government, JNV is a free and fully residential co-educational school system for students
  • She had scored a 9 CGPA in class 10 and 84 per cent in class 12

(Read: CBSE class 10 boards results declared, Kendriya Vidyalaya students steal the thunder )

Support from institutions:  

  • Nayak had applied for a plus three (science course) in Sambalpur College, but she could not continue due to financial constraints
  • Later, Sambalpur GM College offered her a monthly scholarship of Rs. 1000
  • "We visited her village and saw that her parents were financially very weak to carry the burden of the bright girl. We decided to help, as we felt she could go to places with a little push,"said Gupteswar Meher, director of IBS institute

Click here for more on India Today Education
